result.title: Objective
result.description: Increase the protection of livelihoods in coastal areas and island communities from dynamic risks related to climate change and climate variability in all inhabited islands of Tuvalu

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of households in Tuvalu that have increased capacity to anticipate and address climate change-induced risks through targeted adaptation measures

baseline.comment: Coastal communities face climate change risks largely due to lack of adaptive capacity

target.comment: By the end of the project, at least 1000 households in Tuvalu are able to anticipate climate change-related risks and select the most effective risk reduction options

actual.comment: This target level was reported in the 2014 PIR as has been achieved through the delivery of awareness raising programmes to all island communities in the outer islands and on the capital, reaching more than a 1,000 households.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: N. of government officers and planner, Kaupule members and NGO personnel that have increased capacity in identifying climate risks, planning adaptation measures and sustain community awareness on climate chnage issues

baseline.comment:
The countryâ€™s responses to climate change risks and adaptation are ad hoc and piecemeal, and not adequately supported by legislation.
Planners, policy makers, Kaupule, and vulnerable communities are unable to anticipate climate change impacts and integrate these into policy revision, financial planning and decision-making processes

target.comment: At least 200 DoE and DoA officials and planners in other government agencies (DoF, Education, DoH, DMO, PWD) in Tuvalu and in the islandsâ€™ Kaupule, and 30 personnel in NGOs participating in the project (TANGO, NCW) are able to (i) identify climate-induced risks in coastal areas; (ii) prioritize and plan effective adaptation measures on the basis of participatory assessments; and (iii) sustain community awareness of climate change-related risk issues

actual.comment: In July-August 2014, a combined team from the Government including Agriculture, Lands, Public Works, Education, Solid Waste Agency of Tuvalu (SWAT), and non-government institutions including Tuvalu Association of NGOs (TANGO), Red Cross, and Integrated Island Biodiversity (IIB), visited 4 schools (Nauti Primary School, Seventh Day Adventist Primary School, Fetuvalu High School, and Motufoua Form Seven Programme, and the 8 island communities on the Capital (Funafuti, Nui, Nanumaga, Nanumea, Niutao, Vaitupu, Nukulaelae, and Nukufetau) to disseminate climate risk information to school children and island communities. During these visits, a total of 578 people (306 males and 272 females) received a training on climate risk information and its potential impact on food and water security and coastal erosion. In addition, 1,733 school children also received similar information through presentations and quiz.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Outcome 1 Enhanced capacity of public administration , Island Kaupules, communities and NGOs, with policy support to plan for and respond to climate change risks in coastal areas and settlements

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of coastal zone management related policy documents formulated and approved as a result of the project

baseline.comment: There is a lack of an integrated framework and human and institutional capacity for assessing, planning for, and addressing climate change-induced risks at coastal areas or implementing integrated coastal zone management approaches at the national, kaupule, or community levels.

target.comment: By the end of the Project at least 2 National Policies or action plans on coastal management are developed or revised to integrate climate risks and resilience

actual.comment: A National Climate Change Policy - Te Kaniva was endorsed in 2012. This policy was reported in the 2013 PIR

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Existence of a functioning National Climate Change Advisory Council (NCCAC)

baseline.comment: There is no functioning national CC coordination mechanism in place

target.comment: By the end of Year 2, the NCCAC is fully functional in coordinating climate change related policy and development processes

actual.comment: In January 2015, the National Advisory Council on Climate Change (NACCC) was established. It was reported in the 2014 PIR. The project is now actively involved in the NACCC

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: N. of schools capacitated to conduct climate-change related education programmes

baseline.comment: Environmental issues are integrated into school curricula but very limited on climate change topics

target.comment: By the end of the Project, the 10 Primary Schools and 2 Secondary Schools functioning in Tuvalu are capacitated to conduct climate change related education programme

actual.comment: A Curriculum Development officer was funded by the NAPA 1 project to attend the Sandwatch workshop in New Caledonia in December 2014. The outcome of the workshop was a training workshop for teachers around the country in April 2015. The training was facilitated by the Curriculum Development Officer who attended the Sandwatch training. The outcome of the training of teachers is the enhancement of teachers’ ability to teach climate change education programmers in their schools. The next step is to incorporate Climate Change topics into school curricula both at primary and secondary school level.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Outcome 2 Enhanced capacity of local communities to adapt to dynamic climate-related threats through implementation of practical community-based adaptation measures specifically tailored to each islands

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of locally designed, sustainable adaptation measures demonstrated in vulnerable coastal communities

baseline.comment: Disaster management efforts have increased preparedness for extreme events in some areas; however, there is a lack of planned measures and structured analysis of options to implement integrated coastal zone management and adapt to a broad range of both extreme events and gradual climate changeinduced hazards in coastal areas

target.comment: By end of the project, at least 2 community-based adaptation measures employed by the project demonstrate their utility for coastal communities and provide lessons for replication

actual.comment: In December 2014, a team from the Department of Environment, NAPA 1, and an independent EIA consultant visited Nukufetau and Nanumea to assess the likely impacts of coastal interventions on these islands. Works are still continuing on the two islands and will be completed by March 2015.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Outcome 3 Project knowledge and lessons learned are captured, analysed and disseminated to facilitate replication of practical adaptation solutions in all islands

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of knowledge management products generated and disseminated

baseline.comment: Development projects currently do not systematically benefit from learning practices and project lessons on community-based adaptation.

target.comment: Starting from Year 2 of the Project, at least 5 lessons learned and best practises consolidated every year in form of case studies, experience noted, brochures, photo stories, or audio-visuals, and disseminated directly to communities and national stakeholders

actual.comment: Since the last reporting period, there has been very little in-country sharing of lessons learnt except in the form of handing out t-shirts during the National Environment Week, where t-shirts, give-away bags, and caps were distributed to school children, youths, and volunteers.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of national, regional or international events and platforms, where project experience is presented

baseline.comment: Project related climate change information have been only shared during the PPG phase consultation meetings

target.comment: Starting from Year 2 of the project, at least 5 lessons learned and best practises consolidated every year in form of case studies, experience noted, brochures, photos stories or audio-visuals and disseminated directly to communities and national stakeholders

actual.comment: In May 2015, the Interim Project Coordinator attended the Pacific Regional Climate Change Roundtable meeting in Samoa, where lessons learned were shared with colleagues from around the Pacific region.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Availability of sector-specific climate chnage information for projct stakeholders

baseline.comment: Currently there is no regular climate information made available for government planners and NGOs working in development and environmental projects.

target.comment: By the end of the Project, the Government departments and NGO involved in the Project regularly received sector specific climate information to support planning and management processes.

actual.comment: Currently, there are no regular climate change information made available for government departments and NGOs. However, during the World Environment Day and World Biodiversity Day in June 2015, the project contributed to preparing climate change information for students at 2 Primary Schools and 1 Secondary School on Funafuti

result.title: Objective
result.description: Resilience of island communities to climate change variability and risks is strengthened through participatory island-level planning, budgeting and execution and community-led investments

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Take up of climate resilient marine-based livelihood options
Percentage of the Tuvaluan population covered by the 24/7 early warning system
Outer island communities able to access climate/development funds using climate-mainstreamed ISPs

baseline.comment:
Traditional techniques that are resilient to changes in marine ecosystems have been lost or are not passed down by old people while access to new techniques, materials and information from off island and overseas is poor. These are limiting options for pursuing resilient, appropriate and safe low-cost livelihoods.
The existing communications systems are inadequate to send early warning message in a timely manner
No climate resilience investments made using the ISPs as a guiding tool

target.comment:
By the end of the Project at least 40% of the targeted households adopted at least one form of traditional resilient marine livelihood methods (including canoe building, traditional fishing methods, postharvest fish processing, or aquaculture) (gender-disaggregated data will be presented)
95% of Tuvaluan receives early warning in a timely manner using one of the multiple communication lines (gender-disaggregated data will be presented)
By the end of the project at least eight adaptation priority actions (one in each island) at the island level, outlined in ISPs, are financed by either domestic or external resources and executed.

actual.comment:
This indicator has not been achieved.
On-ground activities on building resilience of marine-based livelihoods have not taken place. Depending on the availability of a vessel traveling to outer islands, it is expected that activities will start either in the last quarter of 2015 or first quarter of 2016.
For work related to EWS, preparatory work such as recruitment of a Telecommunication and EWS Expert has been done in order to expedite the procurement of all communications equipment to strengthen the existing communications systems.
For island-level climate finance work, this target will be completed once the CPEIR activity has been carried out and also ISPs have been revised to incorporate climate change actions.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Marine based coastal livelihoods of Tuvaluan outer islands made resilient to declining productivity induced by climate variability and change

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1.1 Households and communities have more secure access to livelihood assets – disaggregated by gender [AMAT 1.3.1]
1.2 The area of Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) or Locally Managed Marine Areas (LMMAs) managed in a climate-resilient manner
1.3 The level of awareness about links between improved marine ecosystem management and sustainability and resilience of subsistence marine-based livelihoods

baseline.comment:
Few households have access to traditional and resilient livelihood assets and methods (Score=2)
Currently 76 km2 of island reef areas is under marine management (includes Funafuti Conservation Area at 33km2) but currently no systematic management arrangement or resource monitoring framework is in place
Current understanding of the links between marine resource monitoring, management and livelihoods is low.

target.comment:
Score improved to 4: By the end of the project at least 50% of targeted outer islands households have access to climate resilient marine-based livelihood methods introduced/strengthened in the project (gender-disaggregated data will be presented)
The area of MPA/MMAs is clarified and some form of management applied to at least a quarter of the reef area on each outer island (area to be calculated) with a corresponding climate-resilient community management plan or Kaupule by-law.
Capacity to undertake creel surveys and maintain the database developed among community-based MPA/MMA management groups.
At least 50% of Fisheries staff, Kaupule, women, youth and fishers interviewed confirm a clear link between resource management and resilience of livelihoods (gender-disaggregated data will be presented)

actual.comment:
In response to the 1st indicator: This target has not been met, as this is an ongoing activity at this moment. There is an ongoing Knowledge, Attitude and Practices (KAP) household survey activity (disaggregated by gender) that the project is implementing right now to assess and verify the amount of households and communities accessed climate resilient marine-based livelihoods
(Score remains at 2 at this point in time).
In response to the 2nd indicator: There has been sharing of knowledge between PMU and Fiji Locally Managed Marine Area - FLMMA (20 participants: 3 from Tuvalu and the rest from Fiji) with regards to the management of marine resources in Suva, Fiji in May this year. Lessons learned from this meeting were crucial as it helps the project plans smartly to engage communities to manage their marine resources in a climate-resilient manner. The outreach activity to the communities on the outer islands will be done in the third quarter depending on availability of vessels.
In response to the 3rd indicator: In April, two workshops were conducted to increase awareness amongst responsible parties about the project and facilitate their active involvement. Amongst the participants, there were 22 men and 9 women.
A Training of Facilitator activity was carried out in June and in this training participants were also taught about the importance of managing their marine resources sustainably for future generations. Beneficial from this activity includes 34 men and 20 women and from these 54 participants, one male participant is a person with disability.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Capacity of outer islands enhanced to respond to increasing/intensifying climate induced hydro-meteorological risks

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 2.1. Relevant risk information disseminated to stakeholders [AMAT 2.1.1.]

baseline.comment: The existing warning/communication system with triple-backup system (satellite phone, landline and electricity-powered radio) is inadequate to warn communities within a reasonable time due to deficiencies in power systems for telephone systems in the outer islands.

target.comment: By the end of the project at least 95% of populations are able to receive and respond to early warnings and take the appropriate actions following the warning (gender-disaggregated data will be presented)

actual.comment: Targets for this outcome have not been met. However, work in progress to recruit a Telecommunication and EWS Expert to help out with acquiring the costing for approved EWS communications equipment. The consultant will be contracted through UNDP.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Enhanced capacity of communities to access internal/external financing for community-based climate change adaptation through existing participatory development planning processes

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
3.1 Local development framework (i.e. ISP)_that integrate climate risks
3.2 Adaptation actions implemented from island level plans (no. and type) [AMAT 1.1.1]

baseline.comment:
Only two islands have some reference to ISPs.
Annual budgeting exercise has been undertaken only in one island.
No adaptation action has been implemented based on Island Strategic Plans

target.comment:
By the end of the project, all outer islands have their ISPs revised to integrate climate risks
Annual budgeting process building on the ISP is in place
By the end of the project at least eight adaptation priority actions (one in each island) at the island level, outlined in ISPs, are financed by either domestic or external resources and executed.

actual.comment:
In response to the 1st indicator: Preparatory works has been done to collate relevant information from Kaupules; the information includes annual budgets and ISPs. As of now the IS Planning and Community Officers have collected all Island Strategic Plans except Nui and Vaitupu’s ISPs. Nui and Vaitupu ISPs are yet to be endorsed by their Falekaupules. These ISPs will be revised in detail by the responsible department (Department of Rural Development) with close consultation with Island Kaupules and Falekaupules. Other useful preparatory works includes the creation of work profiles for Falekaupule and Kaupule members’ for ease references.
In response to the 2nd indicator: This objective will be fulfilled once the ISPs have been revised and adaptation actions included in ISPs.
A (KAP) Knowledge, Attitude and Practices household survey to target Funafuti and Outer Island Communities have started in June and the main objective is to assess the level of knowledge of island communities on various climate change topics to identify specific adaptation priority actions and draw up climate risks for each respective island in line with their ISPs.
